# The Constant Function <GN>

The function <GN> is a constant function that always returns 5, regardless of the input. For any integer x that you provide to <GN>, the output will always be 5.

```
<GN>(10) = 5
<GN>(-3) = 5
<GN>(0) = 5
```

One key property of <GN> is that the difference between any two outputs is always zero. This means that <GN> has a derivative of zero everywhere, making it a perfectly horizontal line when graphed on a coordinate plane.

# Function <JN>: Constant Function

The function <JN> is a constant function that maps any integer input to the value 7. Regardless of what integer is provided as input, <JN> always returns 7.

```
<JN>(3) = 7
<JN>(-10) = 7
<JN>(42) = 7
```

A key property of <JN> is that it has a derivative of zero everywhere, which is characteristic of all constant functions. This means that the output value never changes regardless of how the input changes.

# Function <KN>: Constant Function

The function <KN> is a constant function that always returns the value 9, regardless of what integer input is provided. For any integer x, <KN>(x) = 9.

```
<KN>(1) = 9
<KN>(42) = 9
<KN>(-7) = 9
```

A key property of <KN> is that its graph forms a horizontal line when plotted, as the output value never changes. This makes <KN> useful in situations where a consistent, predictable value is needed regardless of the input parameter.
The function <LN> maps any integer x to 11.

# Function <MN>: Constant Value Function

The function <MN> is a constant function that always returns the value 13, regardless of the input integer provided. For any integer x, <MN>(x) = 13.

```python
# Example usage of function <MN>
print(<MN>(42))  # Output: 13
print(<MN>(-7))  # Output: 13
print(<MN>(0))   # Output: 13
```

A key property of <MN> is that it has a derivative of zero everywhere, making it horizontally flat when graphed. This is characteristic of all constant functions, as they produce the same output regardless of changes to the input value.
